author: Moira McCarthy
title: Savor Summer in New Hampshire | The Herald Traveler |
text:
Visitors can “Live Free and Savor Summer” from now through the end of September by experiencing one of the many late summer events in New Hampshire ( www.visitnh.gov ). Special festivals and fairs celebrating the state’s culinary flare, diverse arts and cultural offerings, classic New England traditions and distinct personalities will be offered throughout the state. Some of the special event choices include:
PRESCOTT PARK ARTS FESTIVAL - Portsmouth, N.H.
Running from now through Aug. 23, the Festival is celebrating its 41st anniversary with a diverse lineup of music, art, theater and dance on the banks of the Piscataqua River in Portsmouth. The festival provides a family-friendly atmosphere, making the event an ideal one for all ages. Events there include:
* William Shakespeare's comedy "As You Like It," with performances scheduled for Aug. 9, 16 and 23.
* Headline concerts each Wednesday night as part of the River House Restaurant Concert Series.
* Performances of Peter Pan will be featured throughout the festival at various dates and times. Peter Pan is presented by C&J Bus Lines.
Details can be found at www.prescottpark.org .
LEAGUE OF NEW HAMPSHIRE CRAFTSMEN'S FAIR - Newbury, N.H.
Through Sunday, Aug. 9
The League of New Hampshire Craftsman Fair runs through Aug 9, and showcases the work of some of the finest craftspeople in the country. Visitors can see and shop for one-of-a-kind fine crafts from more than 350 artists and producers as well as the opportunity to meet the makers and learn about their vision and passion for their craft. Guests can enjoy daily craft demonstrations, participate in workshops, walk through the fair’s Sculpture Garden and take in a variety of strolling performances that feature oversized puppets, magicians, mind readers, musicians, and much more. Details are at www.nhcrafts.org/craftsmens-fair-overview.php .
NORTH COUNTRY MOOSE FESTIVAL – Pittsburgh, N.H.
Friday, Aug. 28 – Sunday, Aug. 30
The North Country Moose Festival runs from Aug. 28-30, and locals say it would be wrong if the region did not honor the mighty moose, its most famous wildlife. The Festival, in its 23rd year, provides family-friendly entertainment centered around moose, while also featuring a classic car show, a craft fair as well as contests and activities for all ages where festival-goers can show off their dancing, cooking, moose-calling, or any other talents. Details are at: www.chamberofthenorthcountry.com/moose-festival.html .
